texts.shortText:
Soles (and the related flounders) are easily recognized as a group, as they have become extremely flattened and lie on their left side, often partially buried in sediment. The eye from the lower, unpigmented, side of the body has migrated to the upper side, which is typically cryptically patterned. Identification to species level is difficult, as there are about 50 regional species and colour patterns are both extremely variable within species and can quickly change in the same individual to match the background.

This species was long known as S. bleekeri, but recent research has demonstrated that to be an invalid name and the correct name should be S. turbynei. The species is best recognized by the distinctive short, black, rounded pectoral fin on the upper side, after which the common name is derived. The bases of the dorsal and anal fins are joined to the tail fin by a membrane and the colour is usually brown with dark spots.

Global: South Africa to Tanzania.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.

Most commonly found in estuaries, but also common in lagoons and on shallow sand banks. Lies on surface sediments on its pale left side. Able to quickly bury itself by flapping the fins, hiding with just the eyes exposed and moving  a short distance forward with an undulating vertical motion if disturbed.
Feed largely on the siphons of bivalves, as well as on small crustaceans, especially amphipods and tanaids.
Matures at 10 cm length and spawns in spring both in estuaries and in the open sea. Small juveniles found mostly in estuaries.

The short, black, rounded pectoral fin is a distinctive character and otherwise colour can be extremely variable between individuals. Several other similar species occur in the regions, but pectoral fin shape can be a useful character to distinguish several of these. For example in the Cape sole Heteromycteris capensis the pectoral fin is entirely absent (and the snout distinctively hooked over the mouth), whereas in the East coast sole Austroglossus pectoralis the pectoral fin is dark but elongate and pointed.
